a particle taking on additional mass temporarily (regardless of the method) seems to violate Newtonian rules, doesn't it? I mean... if we can eject low-mass particles, say, from the back end of a spacecraft toward the front, then do something to increase their mass as they fly, then let them slam into a plate at the front... wouldn't that be a way to propel the craft forward without using the "equal and opposite reaction" method of propulsion we all know and love?

A more efficient means of making muons is creating a GeV electron beam and colliding it with a high Z target like Tungsten. The bremsstrahlung produced should have enough energy to create a muon-antimuon pair near the heavy Tungsten nuclei. Research has actually been done on this:
https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1804/1804.03886.pdf
Fun fact: iron man’s repulser beams use muons because of the similar properties to electrons only that they are heavier
